page.title: 02LOCAL HISTORY THEDDINGWORTH
page.content: The village place name means 'homestead of Peoda's people'. Signs of how people lived in the past are all around us. Fields unploughed since the enclosure show the ridges and furrows of the open field system. The field behind Beeches Farm is marked by ditches and raised areas. Some of these may be evidence of an Iron Age fort, while others show the site of one of the two manor houses, the other having been opposite the Church. On the hillside north of the village can be seen medeival house platforms each side of a road. The thatched house was a slaughterhouse and butcher's shop. The house called Spencerdene was a pub. Two of the cottages next to The Homestead were the bakehouse and the tailor's house. Nearly every house had its own pump and well. Many of these still exist.
